question.title: Question about comparing Java's HashMap `find` method and `tieBreakOrder`
question.body:
I've been studying Java's HashMap and a few questions have come up. Looking at the find method of HashMap, it is written as follows:

else if ((q = pr.find(h, k, kc)) != null)
    return q;
else
    p = pl;

In contrast, other methods in HashMap such as putTreeVal or treeify use the tieBreakOrder method. I'm curious about the difference between these two.

static int tieBreakOrder(Object a, Object b) {
    int d;
    if (a == null || b == null ||
        (d = a.getClass().getName().
         compareTo(b.getClass().getName())) == 0)
        d = (System.identityHashCode(a) <= System.identityHashCode(b) ?
             -1 : 1);
    return d;
}

As I see it, both have commonality in traversing tree nodes - the find method directly traverses the nodes of the tree while tieBreakOrder seems to be comparing several values.

So, I thought about it from the perspective of atomic operations. I assumed that visiting a single node and comparing primitive data values take about the same operation time. As a result, I concluded that the find method – which actually traverses nodes – might be faster than tieBreakOrder, which compares many primitive values.

However, I'm not sure if my assumption is correct, or if there is any other reason that I can understand more about the difference between the find and tieBreakOrder methods?
